A ring R is called commutative if the multiplication is commutative.
Homomorphisms between A-modules, also referred to as A-homomorphisms, are defined just as in the context of vector spaces.
Does the concept of a/an Commutative Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an A-homomorphism to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of an A-homomorphism involves homomorphisms between A-modules, where 'A' typically represents a ring or an algebra that acts on these modules. The definition of an A-homomorphism does not inherently require that the ring A be commutative; it only requires that A be a ring or an algebra. The definition of a commutative ring, on the other hand, specifies a ring where the multiplication operation is commutative. While many interesting cases of A-homomorphisms occur when A is a commutative ring, the general definition of an A-homomorphism does not necessitate that A be commutative. Therefore, the concept of a commutative ring is not necessary for the definition of an A-homomorphism to make sense; any ring or algebra A, whether commutative or not, is sufficient for defining A-homomorphisms.
